text: This beer pours a copper color with a small ring around the top. The nose is citrusy hops, so much so its IPA like the moderate caramel malty backbone shows up after it warms. The flavor is pretty spot on with that nose, with the hops showing at first but then the bready caramel malts take over. Everything is pretty mellow, smooth with a touch of bitterness. Not a bad beer at all.
"darker than most, with a slightly sweeter toffee/caramel thing going on before the slightly bitter finish. not bad, but not great. worth trying, especially if youre an alaskan fan..."
Amber pour with a thin off white head, malty sweet aroma. malty taste with floral hops

Refrigerated 12 oz. brown squat bottle poured into an English pint glass. Clear copper with small beige head. Aroma is caramel malt/light herbal hops, medium body, low carbonation, and little small-bubble lacing. Taste is caramel malt, herbal hops, some floral hops, and bitter finish.

From bottle, pours a reddish amber with a big fluffy off-white head. Lots of fluffy lacing on the glass, too. Aroma is caramel and biscuit and floral hops. Taste is the same, moderately bitter, not particularly sweet, with a light bitter finish.

12 oz bottle consumed in Redwoods Park.
Red-amber; clear; very good tan head; excellent lacing. 
Has a layered, appealing aroma that mixes sweet baked grains with herbal/floral hops. 
Flavor: Given the aroma, theres a rather bold hop note and lingering, moderately bitter aftertaste. Fruity and herbal. 
Feel: Lively medium-high carbonation. Medium body. 
O: bold and hoppy for style.
Beautiful to look at in the glass. Deep rust with a frothy head. In the mouth there is decent malt, but just a tad too much hops for me.

Aroma of sweet bread, and roasted malt. Nice copper amber with a tan head. Nice sweet, caramel malt up front. Notes of roasted malt, hints of toffee, and closes with a nice dry bitterness that blends perfectly with the malty begining. Finishes smooth. Nice example.
Pours slightly hazy amber with small amount of white head. Aroma is roast, toffee and caramel. Nice caramel toffee malt body with a little bit of sweet floral hops. Easy to drink and pretty good.

12 oz bottle- Pours dark autumn amber with a two finger light tan head. Aroma is caramel malt, bright and citrusy which i wasnt expecting. The taste is caramel malt, very ESB, dry finish. Not my style but not bad.

12 oz. bottle from HEB (Braker and 183) served in shaker- poured a mildly darkened amber when held to a light source, one finger slightly off white head formed but DID NOT lace upon the vessel (intriguing...). Aroma of light caramel, an ever so lightly toasted malt, and some love....AHHH! Hits the mouth with a true medium body, malt is just a little slightly sweet, finish has a hint of ash, smoke, and booty. Yep, booty. Just gotta like that.
Bottle. Taste is malt, caramel, wood, grain, wheat and hay. Smooth and very decent.
Solid, if unexceptional. In an ESB, what I look for is slippery mouthfeel and taste. Im getting it here at a 10-20% level. Want m-o-r-e. That said, otherwise this is good.

12 oz bottle. Aroma is toasty, floral. Pours a gorgeous clear copper with a long-sustaining cream-colored rocky head; leaves some lace. Taste is caramelly sweet, finishing with a lightly bitter hop kiss. Creamy mouthfeel, finely carbonated, medium body. More like an American amber ale. Not too bad, but not my thing.

12oz bottle. Overall, Im impressed with the quality of this ESB. It pours a nice rich copper color with good adhesion, clarity, and a nice stable head. Aroma is malty, as advertised, I agree with the floral notes as well. Taste is roasty and crisp, not very hoppy, with a good mouthfeel and nice aftertaste. Malts and breads are there as well, but the crispness at the end will make you forget them. I think its good!
Pours an amber color with a foamy off white head. Notes of caramel, flowers, apricots and baked goods. soft mouthfeel.

Brilliant burnt orange/red. Nose of lemon and orange citrus hops with sweet toasted caramel and light nutty roast. Flavor is candied citrus, orange, caramel, nutty toast. Lingering citrus bitterness and rind. Lightly dry.

Everything is fairly mediocre in regards to appearance and aroma. I did not like the way the beer settled on the palate. It was very light and watery, but does not go down easily. Predictably, the beer has a bitter aftertaste, which Ive come to discover Im not a fan of.

Has crisp color and very full appearance. Nice aroma with a good lead into the beer. Very clean taste, with what is a light bitter aftertaste for am ESB. Not the biggest fan of the style or the beer would get a much higher rating. Still not bad...

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A good aroma of bothering hops. Very hop forward with a simple bitter bite overlaying a crisp malt profile. Slightly sweet on the palate and very refreshing.
bottle. deep copper with small head. smooth malty base with a little bit of nuttiness. mild hops in the finish with very light bitterness.

Clear brilliant copperish amber under a foamy light beige head. The aroma is sweet and nutty with a touch of maple and vanilla yogurt. The taste is a bit medium bodied with a dry metallic-ish finish, but throughout there is a bit of earthy toast and dry biscuity toffee. Bit of a letdown.

Bottle. Pours beautifully - deep maroon brown with khaki head. Nose is one of the nicest American ESBs Ive head from a major brewer - subtle but several layers of floral hops perceptible against a pleasing and dominant bready malt. Flavor profile that follows is similar but has deep roasty notes and is stacked just a bit towards resiny and floral hops near the end. My favorite regular seasonal from Alaskan and I have to say that most of their beers are exceptional if not wild enough to fetch top ratings..

Poured from 12 oz bottle into schooner glass.

Appearance: pours a 1" frothy cream colored head which recedes with plenty of lacing. Dark amber color and lots of streaming carbonation.

Aroma: very pleasant aroma of spicy hops, toffee, cinnamon, some fruit, and a malty backbone.

Mouthfeel: fairly light and prickly mouthfeel, somewhat sticky on the palate.

Flavor: pine and citrus hops, raisin, toffee, whole wheat bread.

Overall: a very delicious smelling and tasting beer. Interesting American version of the classic English style.
Not so bitter, very drinkable and easy to enjoy with some nice food at a cabin during a snow storm. NIce colour and aroma.

~Toasty bready malt aroma with strong floral and earthy hops. Very pleasant and well balanced aroma.
~Pours a clear copper color with small wispy off white head.
~Bready malt with a slight sweetness followed up with a burst of floral earthy hops.
~Medium bodied with medium high CO2, lingering bitterness and a bite that only ale yeast can provide. 
~ Really enjoying this one. Have had several at different times of the day and after different meals. Is good any time. Good all around brew to have on hand.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2014 Fairly clear amber color with a thin head and moderate carbonation. Aroma of floral hops, toffee, pale & munich malts and yeasts. Flavors of floral hops, bitter hops, yeasts, munich malts and light toffeeness. Floral Hop and light malty aftertaste. Tastes almost like an English Pale Ale. Light body and mild-moderate carbonation. Tastes great!

Amber brew with a sweet aroma with some hints of floral hops. Taste is mostly a toasted bread with slight caramel. The hops dont really do much to improve upon that. When held on the toungue a bit there is an off metalic taste. Best to just drink it down. Overall a decent brew but not something I would want to call ESB.

Deep red-tinted amber color. Over-adequate bubbling holds a tall beige head. This foamy lace. Hoppy English malt aroma with dark toasted biscuit. Flavor starts sweet and rolls into perfectly balanced beer taste with the hops finishing up o.ly slightly bitter. Very good ESB. Other.than the alcohol content is too high at 5% Im very impressed.

Draught at Alaska Lodge (Sea-Tac Airport)Dark amber color with compact head. Smell of cleaning products (the glass?) and some nice caramel. Strong caramel flavor with a mild animal component. Strong bitterness. Not really an ESB, more an American thing; not bad.

Dark orange pour with a white head. The aroma has some strong biscuit malt notes with a bit of grass. The flavor is very similar. I get some biscuit malt, grass and a hint of orange citrus. The bitterness level is fairly low. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Very nice.
12 oz bottle. Deep amber with a decent off-white head head. Aroma is of spicy hops, herbal, toffee, pine, floral notes. Taste is of bitter florals, spicy hops, woody notes, earth, and moss.

Bottle. The look is a nice white lacing head, the color is amber, and is almost clear. The smell is caramel, fruits, malts, deep, floral, and nice. The taste is malts, caramel, fruits, hops, florals, and crisp.
Good beer. Dry bitter taste. Earthy and woody taste. Good for a relaxing evening. Toast
Bottle. Rich amber pour with a small spotty head. Grassy hop with a hint of citrus. Malty, slightly earthy. Crisp and clean. Quite good.

This pours a clear, dark amber color with a slight beige head. The aroma is slightly malty with a touch of bitter hops. The taste is bold with just the right amount of hops that leaves a dry after taste. This is quite a well made ESB and a very well made beer, its well worth giving a try!

Bottle - Has a tea color with a thick tan head with chunky lacing and nice retention. Has an initial grassy hop taste but a malty backbone and a dry bitter finish. Not my favorite style but I like this one.
Aroma is dry malts, light berries/fruit and a hint of pine. The flavor is malts, fruit/berries, light citrus/grapefruit and a dryish finish.

12 oz serving from a 6-pack from Fred Meyer in S.Salem.
$6.99(6).
Clear hazel nut brown colour with a large creamy thick eggshell white head.
Hoppy aroma first..citrus,orange.papaya..not expected for style but nice .Slightly caramel malts in the back.
Taste is more like style with the caramel malts taking a better place.Hops still there..PNW style. Its fine enough.
Mouth feel is fine and the beer is medium carbonated.
OK beer but not the best and the hops are not to style.

Pours amber with an off white head. Malt, hop, biscuit, floral and caramel aroma. Biscuit, malt, hop, floral, caramel, citrus and grass flavors. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Slight bitterness and a biscuit finish.
Bottle from Kroger. Light, brownish pour with a small head. Aroma is grainy and a little citrus. Taste is old bread, bitter, and an awkward finish.
Draft. Its an ESB gone american. Not particularly special but quite solid and drinkable.

From the 355 ml. bottle. Received in trade. The pour is very nice with its chestnut brown color and modest cream head. Good clarity. When I smell bitters I expect caramel and toasted malts and I do get that but it is also very floral and hopped up. Medium body. The taste does begin with the caramel toasted malts and biscuit character but the floral and bitter hops really present themselves at the end.

Bottle received in trade from BeerKangaroo, thanks for the opportunity!
Pours a crystal clear deep copper color with a huge bubbly off white head that persists forever. Aromas of brown sugar and caramel with hints of dark dried fruit and bits of sulfur and earth. The flavor is what I expected from the aroma. Light dark sugary malts with bits of earthy hop light fruit and hints of sulfur. Medium to light body with a moderate level of carbonation and a slick almost sweet mouthfeel. Nice drinker, not really my favorite style, but this is a well made brew.

Bottle - Pours rosy brown with a foamy tan head. Nose is grassy, piney hops over a dry bready malt base. A little spicy. Taste is the same--dry, piney hops, dry bread, a bit of caramel, some grass--pretty astringent. Medium-bodied and fluffy. Super disappointed in this one.

12 oz bottle from Mile High Wine & Spirits into a pint glass. Amber and clear with a lasting, sticky white head. Aroma of floral hops, bread, sweet malts (caramel, toffee), herbs and light skunk. Similar flavor, malty and bittersweet with a medium body and a crisp, smooth finish. Pretty solid ESB.

Welcome back, old friend! It has been far too long.

An amazing clear deep copper produces a long lasting off white head that leaves behind beautiful lacing.... One of the prettiest beers ever.

Nose is big floral hops with some light grassy hoppiness... plenty of dry toast/dry caramel maltiness that helps balance but never smells sweet... perhaps a light fruity ester, but that could be in my imagination.

Flavor is very well balanced... dark caramel presence meshes well with the floral hops and some background earthy hoppiness.. significantly more bitterness lets you know this is of PNW origin and gives a nod to the Continental ESBs... With warmth a light nutty element arises and adds to the complexities.

Smooth with a light carbonation.

This is a great brew... Definitely "American", but still a great take on an ESB... Somewhere, DING is getting angry as I type this and he doesnt even know why. :-)
Not sure Id ever find an ESB to be excellent but this ones pretty good. Caramel malt with fruity and floral notes and a nicely bitter finish.

Pours a clear dark amber with creamy head and good lacing. Aroma is earthy, herbal, with caramel. Taste is malt forward, nutty in the middle with a decent lingering bitterness. Palate is high, soft carbonation and medium body. Not bad, not my favorite style.

Bottle. Nose is actually hoppier than I expected, and has some nice floral bits to it, implying a lot of freshness to it. Taste has just a bit of roasting in there that blends nicely into some bitterness. Much like an APA brewed with some darker malts. Very nice.

amber pour with a quick thin head.
aroma is very appetizing roasted malt, fruit, caramel and floral hop. 
Flavour is toasted malt, piney and floral hop. caramel malt backing that.

From a bottle. Nice brown color floral and fresh aroma. Roasted and floral flavor. Definitely a Northwest esb. Still drinkable with some bitterness and quite enjoyable 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Clear red-amber with fluffy cream colored head. Aroma of toast, grass, and light pine. Taste is toasty and mildly bitter. Light-medium bodied. Good.

12oz bottle-trade with SHIG thanks!-had this at the brewery about 3 years before I started rating, so glad to get this one under my belt as a rate and SHIG is convincing me to return to Alsaka for a 3rd trip. Lt tan-copper. A-pine/some citrus, lt malt. T-herbal/pine hops, lt/med malt-toasty.
Red brown pour some head. Aroma of pine caramel. Tastes caramelly hay. Super smooth mouthfeel yet refreshing. could have more hops.

22oz bottle. Clear copper with a light beige head. Aroma of bread dough and herbal hops mostly with light caramel and citrus. Flavor is balance with toasty malt and bitter hops. Medium body with average carbonation. Easy drinking beer.
For a malt forward brew it was pretty damn tasty. Candi sugar with some caramel and dark fruit. Smooth drinking beer
Bottle. Pours brown with red hues, off-white head. Smells very caramel, nutty, sweet fruits. Has a medium body, bitter balanced with a bit of malt. Really good.

Copper pour, slight head. Roasted malt and light Pacific Northwest hops in the nose. More bitter than sweet. Middle is caramel and hearty bread. Finish is dry and nicely bitter. Balanced, delicious beer. Good with ham steak.

Bottle @ home, picked up at Wilburs Fort Collins. An old favorite that Im glad to see back. Pours a clear rust orange appearance with a good sized brown head. Slightly nutty, cookie/doughy, piney, light citrusy hoppy aroma. Chewy toasted malty, cracker/doughy, somewhat bitter piney, earthy flavor. Some bitterness on the finish but not too harsh. Not as good as I remember but not too bad.

Pours copper red. Smell is mild and tea like with a bit of sweet gummy malt. Taste is watery, bland and moderately bittered with tea flavor. Very subtle flavor and pretty bland and boring...how is this rated so well?
Great smell, and initial flavor as it hits your tongue. But after that, the beer tastes too sweet, not bitter at all.
Malty goodness on the nose and a pleasant well-balanced finish. Haven't met an Alaskan that isn't a great beer and this one is no exception.

Pours a finger of head on a cloudy dark straw colored body.
The aroma is wet grain with mild lemon. Nice.
The taste is balanced moderate lemon bitterness with mild honey sweetness.
The texture is crisp with moderate carbonation.
This ESB has a great balance and is quite drinkable.
Bottled, red orange pour with creamy foam, caramel nose, hoppy pine flavor with some bitter caramel, metallic finish

Appearance is an amber to dark red almost brown colored body that shows some transparency to it. One finger white foamy head dies within thirty seconds. Speckled spider web lacing leaves some rings. The aroma provides some earthy yet bitter hops and caramel malts not as "English" smelling as some Ive had and perhaps coming through a bit more hoppier for Americans. The taste packs some earthy and still packing some bitter hoppiness with some nutty tones coming out; definitely shows the English side a bit more in the taste; it has a dry bitter aftertaste and finish. Its pretty easy on the palate. Overall, a good ESB by an American company. Ill have another.

Best by 14MAR14

Pours lovely dark amber with a good sheet of lighter foam and nice lace. Initially, when I poured this, got a solid bubble gum nose, then smells of roasty malts, some pine and a little graham. flavor is bready, a little hay, some bitterness, roasty brown ale character, soft yeast notes. Medium on full bodied with moderately low carb and a dry finish. Meh, not what I expect from an ESB
Decent ESB.  Caramel malts on the nose, and start of the flavors.  Slightly nutty and toasty in the body, tender spice hop note towards the finish that lingers nicely.

12oz bottle.   Medium red with a medium off-white head.   light haze from bottle conditioning.   Lots of earthy dark caramel in the aroma, with a touch of candied or dried fruit and an herbal side.   The flavor is squarely malty with a lot of dark crystal malt dominating the profile.   Earthy bitterness wraps up the finish, but doesnt quite overcome the malt flavors.   Medium bodied with soft carbonation.   At least this isnt a over-hopped bastardization of the strong bitter style, but it does lean a tad too much on the dark crystal.
Beautiful light red pour in glass. Beer is sweet and slightly bitter. Pleasant finish. Rated 8/14/02

Alaskan Brewing Company--Frontier American Ale--1998 12 oz. Bottle Release.  5.00% ABV.  (3.75 / 5.0)  Amber Ale--Rich clear amber red color.  Light floral hoppy front with touches of spice and fruit.  Caramal malt body is light but rich with flavor and develops as brew finishes.  Light bitter finish.  Nice!  Sampled 2/6/1999.

Alaskan Brewing Company--ESB--2000 12 oz. Bottle Release.  5.00% ABV.  (3.5 / 5.0)  ESB--Rich clear bright copper color.  Light earthy hop ESB front.  Flavorful lightly toasted caramel malt body.  Malty earthy classic smooth ESB flavor with smoky notes, light body and nice hop blend.  Sampled 5/2/2000.

Alaskan Brewing Company--ESB--Extra Special Bitter Ale--New Logo	2003 12 oz. Bottle Release.  5.00%	 ABV--35 IBUs.  (3.75 / 5.0)  ESB--Light mild lace head.  Clear bright thin amber ruby color.  Toasted malty floral mild hop front.  Sweet thin toasted caramel fruit body.  Mild earthy crusty biscuit hints.  Tangy sweet mild hop end.  Sampled 8/6/2003.

Alaskan Brewing Company--Alaskan ESB--Extra Special Bitter Ale--Yellow Cap Version--2004 12 oz. Bottle Release	.  5.00% ABV--35 IBUs.  (4.0 / 5.0)  ESB--Creamy lacy head.  Clear bright dark amber red color.  Toasted mild fruit hop front.  Toasted mild earthy caramel fruit body.  Dry sweet biscuit notes.  Clean creamy balanced mild hop bitter end.  Mild.  Sampled 4/24/2004.
Bottle.  Pours a copper toned body with an off white head.  Caramel and nutty tones, with some light floral hops.  Light and dry with a mildly bitter finish hints of toast.  Decent.

One of the Bottle I have been wanting for years. I dont know why. My man Toby found this in Montana thanks a lot. Pours out a golden topped with a small head. Aroma of light caramel and floral hops. Taste was more of the light floral hops along with some wood.

I think we decided this was a 2007 Bottle - Thanks BuckeyeBoy! - Pours a clear amber with a small tan head...aroma is malty and grainy, the hops still present and floral...flavour is moderately bitter, old grain, dry malt, hay...more lingering bitterness in the finish...never thought Id ever taste that one...

Bottle - thanks BuckeyeBoy.  Glowing amber pour with a thin beige head.  Nice aroma is a blend of sweet citrus and maltiness.  A bit of faded hops.  Red licorice comes to mind...  Tastes of faded florals, caramel, and grassey.  Comes through a bit aged.  Still pretty decent.
Pours copper with an off white head.  Smells of sweet caramel, some rosey hints.  Tastes yeasty, sweet and earthy.  Average.
Pours a dark brown, almost copperish, with a tan head.  Aroma of citrus, hops, honey, and roasted malts.  Flavor is earthy, with caramel and toasted malt.  Nice balance of hops on the finish.

Bottle. Pours a golden copper color that is slightly cloudy with a foamy tan head. Very,  nice malt aroma but also a bit toasty. Aroma is very nice, but not much there. A great palate balance. Nutty and malty, some caramel sweetness a toasty malt and more nuttiness. There is a very pleasant hop balance. This is a good beer from beginning to end.
Copper colored.  Thin head malt aroma and taste.  Bitter finish like youd expect from an ESB.  Meduim body.  Better than average.
Bottle sampled at Alans initiation, thanks Dogbrick:  Aroma is honey and roasted malts.  A bit bready.  Flavor is earthy, roasted, a tad sweet and a tad nutty.  Smooth, bitter finish.
user_location: I F&ckin hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text: Dark brown sugar color with a foamy rich head and nice lacing. Soft nose of wet hops and earth. Flavor is smooth with a good English ESB flavor. Very nice beer.

Sample in the Alaskan tap room. This brew is a lightly hazed copper color with a medium thin and foamy off-white head that diminishes steadily. Rings of lacing on the glass. Hops, citrus and earthy malt aroma. Medium-bodied and moderately bitter with hops, caramel and biscuity malt flavors. The finish is hoppy and lingering, with a touch of sweetness in the mix. Above average overall.
This brown ale poured with a decent beige head and a floral aroma. The flavor is dominated by hops, but there is some balancing malt. The finish is chalky and bitter.

To me this is a really great ESB.  Nice bready maltiness, bordering on doughy, and then a pleasant zing of hoppiness, has a bit of earthy minerality as well.  As the beer continues the hops definitely steal the show, but still seems to remain crisp and balanced.

Received 12-oz bottle via trade with 5000. Pours a hazy dark amber brew with a thick off-white head that has some good retention and sticky lacing that stays with the glass. Aroma of roasted caramel malt, a good balance of flowery and citrus zest hops, a touch of dark berry character. Taste is medium bodied, light carbonation with a extra mild bitterness along with flavors of multi-grain biscuit malt, floral and citrus zest with a hint of pine. Finish has a dry bitterness with some secondary malt aftertaste. Thanks to André for helping me acquire this excellent brew.

Thanks to Skyview.  Pours a nice Brownish amber.  Nice super citrusy and sweet malt nose.  Medium carbonation with a good dose of citrus coming through on the palate.  Nice solid ESB, and very easy drinking.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: 12 oz bottle-trade w/snojerk321. Cloudy amber color w/ a slight head & good lacing. Sweet, citrus aroma. Bitter hop flavor on the front end w/traces of pine, peat, caramel, & yeast. Very earthy brew w/a nice bitter finish. Could use a little more of a malt finish for my taste, kind of out of balance. Good beer though, thanks Torry!
One of the better ESBs ive tried.  12 oz bottle.  Pours a medium amber with a frothy tan head.  Nose of spice, caramel, roasted malts, and some hops.  Nice clean finish.....just right.

Amber-gold with a medium off-white head.  Aroma is sweet with some light earthy-citrus hops and very bready caramel malts.  Flavor is very bready - lots of caramel, honey, and spice mixing with some subtle earthy-citrus hops.  Clean finish.  Good ESB.
on Tap Hamiltons. Wet pallete and rmid bodied ale with a nice rich auburn color and great head retention. Biscuit, caramel and a crisp dry hop finish. A really good ESB

Great classic bitter pour...golden and foamy.  The nose is a bready caramel malt and substantial earthy hoppiness.  Flavors are likewise caramel bread dough and biscuity with a nicely balanced bitter hop bite...earthy and pretty substantial.   Very satisfying, yet, ironically, extremely repeatable!

Bottle Code of A082007, Sampled September 2007
Pours with a brilliantly clear, deep, ruby-red color and is topped by a frothy, initially three-finger thick, amber-tinged, tan colored head that leaves some lacing on the sides of the glass as it slowly recedes.  The beer has an interesting aroma of strawberries that I notice as I am pouring this brew into my tulip glass.  Closer inspection of the aroma makes out that fruity note to be hop derived, though it seems more like a combination of candied citrus peel and berries than of the initial strawberry note.  A herbal / pine like hoppiness is also here, and at time is fairly noticeable.  This really has an enticingly hoppy nose to it; I am quite enjoying it.  Sweet, caramelized malt sugar notes and toasty grain aromatics form a backdrop to the up front, more dominant hop character.

A slightly creamy mouthfeel, that has a touch of fizziness from the carbonation.  The beer is quite quaffable, fairly light, yet substantial enough to be noticed as it sits in the mouth.  The beer finishes with a solid bitterness as well as a menthol like herbal flavor, both of which contribute to a lingering astringency on the tongue.  The beer is only lightly sweet (though I had a lemonade recently so take that for what it is), but has a rich caramelized grain character.  There also seems to be a touch of toasted malt, almost even chocolate character here; this is fairly subtle, but adds a nice, extra dimension to the malt.  The hops and malt combine to give this beer a nice fruitiness that reminds me of oranges, berries and maybe even raisins.

This is quite a nice beer; it is very quaffable and I would definitely be happy drinking quite a few pints of these (before I know it, my 12oz pour is gone).  I really like the hop character here and how it combines with the substantial, yet secondary, malt character.

Purchased: <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Tucson, AZ

dark amber in color with a medium off-white head.
smell - citrus, hops (smells very bitter),roasted pumpkin seeds.
taste - a bit metallic, bitter, some orange is in there too, leaves the mouth on the dry side.
good beer, a little watery for me and i wish it was more bitter.

8/12/2007:  Alaskan ESB produces a nice pour.  It is a beautiful, clear rich honey/amber-orange color with a lasting, frothy beige head.  The carbonation looks just right and well dispersed.  The aroma exhibits a caramel maltiness with a nice, citrus and pine hop presence.  The flavor is a bit earthy and is well-balanced between a nice caramel maltiness and a gentle, yet somewhat substantial hoppiness (floral with hints of orange and pine) thats perfect for style . This beer has a medium body and is soft, smooth, and mellow on the palate.  Overall this is a good ESB that is right on the money.  It is flavorful, true to the style, moderate alcohol, and hightly sessionable.  Ive had a few beers from Alaskan Brewing Company and am continuously impressed with their offerings.
12 fl oz bottle (K A090407) from bitbucket.  Thanks Bob!  Rating #143 for this beer...

[436-20070725]  355mL (w/ jerc, tuqueboy). Faint wheaty yeast aroma, some malt. Clear, dark red amber body with a medium-lasting foamy off-white head. Nice malty flavour thats a little hoppy. Medium body is slightly astringent. Nice blending could be pepped up a little more.

Bottle courtesy of Mabels parents. Dark amber body with a small fluffy off-white head. Lightly earthy, moderately hoppy aroma. Similar flavour, sweet notes of caramel malt. Earthy, lightly astringent finish. Pleasant bitterness with brief hints at citrus. Average to thin palate. 7/3/7/3/14

A thin, mostly diminishing off-white head tops a translucent amber with rusted copper highlights. Spotty lacing is nicely, evenly dispersed. Floral, earthy and garlic scented hop notes lead in the aroma. Very hoppy, more than expected. Onion, orange and chamomile scents appear next. the nose has plenty of toasted malt, as well as substantial backing semi-sweet caramel. This really doesnt seem like a pleasant blend, especially when repeated nosing yields a burned caramel character that starts to overtake what awkward hop profile already made its case to the court. The flavor is a bit more pleasing but its also rather muddled. Bitterness is moderate, sweetness is as well. Astringency grows steadily. There are some nice cake icing notes that develop after each sip. Finishes mildly bitter, fading to caramel, weird and vegetal. The mouthfeel is medium bodied, with zippy carbonation and a good overall balance in weight and aggression. Not bad, not something Ill return to either.

Pours a clear red-orange with just the smallest little swirly off white head.  It has a hoppy, fruity aroma, some sweet malts mixed in too.  The taste is definiely hoppy, although nothing overpowering.  Decent malt backbone to give it some structure.  Balanced fairly well so it seems.  I get a little bit of a sweet cinnamon taste towards the finish and somewhatlingers in the aftertaste, which also becomes slightly bitter.  Not a bad drinking beer at all.

Bottle courtesy IrishBoy via trade. Pour was copper shaded amber, nice off-white head, a little rocky fluffy, excellent lacing. The aroma was tea bags, toffee, caramel. The flavor was tea bags, toffee, caramel, light roast, a much more intense flavor profile than the Pale, yet very similar. Mouthfeel was full, frothy, pretty nice. Thanks, Richard!

Bottle. Pours coppery amber with a lacy off-white head. Fruit, citrus and floral hop aroma. Light body and medium carbonation. Caramel and fruit sweetness with a moderately bitter and flowery finish. Nice!
Very standard ESB which might win you something at a competition, but I expected better from my first taste of this brewery I had heard so much about.

(a gift from irsihboy....thanks sir!)bronze body with a creamy white head that leaves some webbing.sweet caramel aroma with a hint of hop bitterness.flavor boasts much of the same with a hint of honey.
Good appearance and good head retention.Good creamy palate but unfortunately, lacks flavor. This could be much better than it is.

Aroma of floral hop and malt. Seems balanced. Red copper color with a light beige head. It seems to lace. As the glass approaches the nose, the malt aroma dominates. A strong carbonation. Then roasted, but not dark, malt overwhelms things. Ends a bit watery and malty sweet. But when the malty sweetness drains away, there is some noticeable hop bitterness. I dont think its balanced, but there is interplay.
Draft. Bronze beer with an off-white head. Slight citrus, caramel aroma. Caramel, toffee flavor with backing citrus. Lingering toffee. Medium body.

12oz Bottle
A good golden color with a nice head,  A decent hoppy aroma with a slight bready maly nose.  Misses the ESB style but the beer was good to drink, For a bitter it was too light int he bitter flavor.  Needs work on the bitter end.  Ouch did I say that.

excellent hop and malt balance.  a little too hoppy for esb style.  pours a nice ruby/copper color with little head.  very nice beer but not to style.  it would probably get killed in a competition due to this.

Bottled 
Amber colour. Citric aroma from hops and very tea-like. Resiny flavour with a wonderful hop profile, thats fresh and citrusy.  Very well balanced, maybe a bit one-dimensional.

bottle: pours nice carmel colour small fizzy head. aroma of citrusy hops very strong hop aroma over caramel malts. a little watery to start but finishes well with a nice clean bitter hop. nice sessionable esb
Everything in moderation here.  Amber color, caramel malty body with mild grapefruit bitterness.  Crisp, semi-sweet finish.  Refreshing!

First time trying an ESB. Not as ESB as I thought but still very good. Pour a nice bark brown and had a nice thick foam head that lasted a while. The smell was a little week from an ESB in my opinion. The taste and drinkability were both really good.

beer pours a ruby-tinted amber, with a well-formed head (white w/orange tints) that retains and laces well. nose a nice balance of caramel malts and earthy hops. flavor a good blend of sweetness and earthy hop bitterness, with a light body. pretty good drinker - a fair amount of flavor, but not heavy or anything.
Golden amber body with light white head.  Aroma is lots of citrus hops.  Dry on the mouth throughout with nice citrus hops flavouring the beer.  Good but nothing overly special.
Copper color with a decent sized head. Sweet malt with a little hop bitterness.

Draught.  Pours clear amber with a small white rocky head, somewhat diminishing with good lacing.  Aroma is average malt (straw, grain), light hops (grass), average yeast (sweat) with notes of apples and roasted vegetables.  Average duration, light sweetness, moderate acidity and bitterness; husky grain and sour yeast flavor.  Medium bodied, sticky texture, average carbonation and a metallic, bitter finish.

From the local COOP.  12 oz botle.  Poured copper with small white head and minimal lacing.  Nose of malts, hops, caramel, citurs, and spices. Mouthfeel is smooth and it feels good on the back of thej palate.  Flavor is rich malts.  Great hoppy finish.  Very enjoyable and easy to  drink.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2007 Smells just like an APA with a tiny bit more malty stuff.  Has a nice, clear reddish copper appearance with a small white head.  Caramel malts at first with a big hoppy finish Very well balanced and I really enjoy the malts in this one.  I will buy it again when Im looking for a nice change of pace.  As somebody said before, its definitely an American ESB with lots of hops.  A rather pleasant and easy drinking one Id definitely recommend.
This is a very good ESB.  The Alaskan Brewing Company sure does know how to make a great beer, and this is no exception.  If you want a good ESB, give this one a try.
Pours amber with a decent head. Aroma is malty caramel, some fruity hoppiness. Starts sweet, slightly bitter finish.
Gift from IrishBoy.  Reddish- brown color.  off-white eggshell head.  Spice grapefruit aroma.  Rich malt flavor, with a killer hop finish.  Very light bodied.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2006 I was pleasantly suprised by this one. Its different from a British ESB, but I like this one.  I would drink this again and I have 1 left but will be a nice guy and give it to grim.
GABF 06.  Aroma is citrus hops and caramel malt.  Taste is sweet caramel malt followed by citrus hop bitterness.  Well done.

Bottled.
Amber color, small tan head. bready, hoppy, quite APA/IPA-like aroma. Very malty, a bit of citrus, then burst of hoppy bitterness. not similar to English ESB - really American version. Long bitter aftertaste. Nice balance of hops and malts.

Bottled. Amber/copper coloured, small head. Aroma is American hops, just lovely in this one. Flavour is grassy, caramellish and very dry. Aftertaste is hayish and grassy hops. Boring, if compared to the aroma.
A strong but not overpowering taste, a pleasant, a sweet caramel aroma. A Pleasant ESB with a pleasant lasting taste.

via trade with IrishBoy - Pours a clear amber color with a nice off white head.  Lots of lacing.   Aroma is light caramel malt.  Light malt flavor with some nice hop bitterness.  A smooth, medium body beer.  A nice easy drinking beer.  Thanks Richard.

Appearance: Pours a transparent amber copper color with a decent of f white head and great lacing. 

Smell: The aroma is toasty and malty with hints of caramel. The hops are very reserved but present as a light grassy attribute. There is also a hint of diacytel in the nose along with a slight smell of egg whites.

Taste: This is a very balanced beer with a nice toasty caramel malt flavor. There seemed to be hints of dough early in the flavor. There is a nice light hint of fruit along side a very bready body. As it warms the diacytel and a tea like character showed up more. I got distracted with my babies waking each other up and it did get a bit too warmed in the mid of my tasting. However, I was very pleased with the beer and found it to be very easy drinking. The orange-ish hops showed up more in the finish and the aftertaste. 

Mouthfeel: Magnificently smooth mouthfeel that is near perfect except the medium body goes a bit limp through the center. Still, very creamy and quaffable.

Drinkability: Simply put, this beer is irresistible! Simple and yet elegant in that simplicity; this is a very well crafted drinking beer!

Hope this is helpful.
Cheers!

Body is a brown amber with a thin offwhite head.  Aroma is hoppy with, some honey and caramel, along with hints of chocolate, and dried fruit. Initial  taste is caramel, with the light hop background fading in and a lingering bitterness at the end that is rather pleasant.  On the palate it is a little bit fizzy.

12oz bottle via trade with IrishBoy - Thanks Richard! - Pours copper with a tall offwhite creamy head that stays well and laces the sides of the glass.  Aromas of caramel, and grassy hops.  Flavor is alot of caramel, toffee, and a few earthy notes finished with some light grassy hops and slight bitterness. Medium bodied and light carbonation.  Very smooth and creamy and a pretty nice bitter to drink..
12 oz bottle; Nose of caramelly malts and a little hops; dark amber wit a huge beige head; flavor is bitter with some caramel and spice in the background.

12-oz. Pours a darkish amber with a little tan head. Sweet malt, caramel, and some fresh mown grass in the nose--Alaskan can be stingy with the aromas, so this is nice. Fizzy body; the bubbles really step through on the attack, all the way to the finish. Caramel/nougaty palate. The hops hold up from the beginning to the end--nice. Those sweet malts clamber over at the finish, though, leaving an oddly sour linger. The hops should probably have been left alone to do their thing for the finish with this one.
Small white head, very good grapefruit aroma, bitter more than malty but overall balanced. Decent nicely drinkable bitter, though a bit watery. A few days after expirey
12oz bottle- Aroma of hops and floral on a ruby red body with a head that dissipated quickly. A nice hoppy and malt combination. A medium bodied beer. A nice ESB.

Mostly translucent and scarlet mahogany in color with dusty ice glacier of grey for the head.  Pine nuts and spruce toffee kickstart the aroma, pursued by neglected Christmas tree nurseries, rye, juniper berry and cherry cream oats.  Light flavor rolls in with liquefied English toffee thats been stowed for a year or more.  Sweetened bran flakes and a piney spruce praline fulfillment.  Nutmeg and pepper spice with a flavor akin to cherry butterscotch graham cracker crust.  Prickly and pincing carbonation hits the palate and gives was to a semi-syrup viscosity.  Hop selection seems ill-advised and it doesnt seem to have dropped enough gravity points.  Toffee, maple and a touch of Christmas spice, mulberry and brown sugar wrap-around in the finish.  Thanks for the bottle, tpkenned!

12 oz bottle from lees liquor: A high quality ESB from Alaskan brewery, still some haze floating around after the pour-perhaps not filtered.  Big hop flavor but not overpowering, with just the proper amount of malt.  Good example of the style.
A fine example of the Brits style redone with that NW flavor. I found it very enjoyable wish it was available in Florida
twelve ounce bottle, nice light yellow with floral nose, crisp bitterness and a slight toffee aftertaste, Excellent crisp hoppy brew

From bottle at the Juneau airport.  Delicious.    Extremely balanced with a nice hoppy bite.  Nice spiciness in the hop profile.  Nice american hop flavors, but none of the overly-citrus american hop flavors; perfect for the style. I had to drink 3 in one sitting before Id had enough.
(Bottle)  Pours a clear amber body with a large creamy beige head and good lacing.  Aroma of citrus, florals, and caramel.  Flavor of caramel malt and mild hops with a dry finish.

Good, dense, nearly pink coloured head; red-chestnut colour, clear. Very perfumey, near almondy nose, malts abundant, cherry stones. Surprisingly bitter beer, hoppy taste, with just enough malt backing to feed it. Again something almondy retronasal, warming up. Very creamy, smooth MF. Medium bodied. Aftertaste yields dry hops. Best about it is its balance. It even can be refreshing, served cool.

From a short 12oz. brown bottle with a best before date on the lower right hand side of the front label, 04/22/06. Made a decent appearance, poured a clear bright amber with a foamy beige head that settled into a thin lacing, moderate carbonation overall. Sweet toasted, fruity malt nose with a fresh, leafy hoppiness. A crisp, textured, smooth medium bodied feel, very good drinkability. Buttery, toasted grainy and caramel malty taste upfront, a nice rolling citric hoppiness in the middle, crisp in its bitterness and a sweet toasted malty finish with a little citric bitterness lingering in the palate.
A balanced and tasty ESB, if you like the style, I would recommend trying this.
Pours brown with a small white head.  Refreshing, fairly smooth and crisp.  Pretty good esb, it doesnt have that odd flavor that most of the ESBs do.  Pretty good, Id drink it agian.

12oz. bottle.  Ruddy orange-amber with a tall off white head.  Caramel, malt sweetness, and fruity hops in the aroma.  Deep mellow caramel flavors with spicy/herbal and resinous/citrus hop components.  Residual sweetness and some astringent bitterness in the finish.  Mouthfeel is medium, somewhat dry.
Very clear light pale amber color with nice caramel flavor in taste and aroma. Nice bitterness and clean dry finish. Very drinkable

clear amber body with a nice white and lacey head, a weak slightly hoppy slightly malty nose, citrus, well balanced hop malt ratio, crispy and delicate palate, refreshing and clean, in my opinion it could use a some beefier hop bitters, but it is a pretty damn good beer just the way it is, and I will love it for who it is

This bottled brew poured a large sized head of finely sized mostly lasting off-white colored bubbles that left behind a good lacing.  The body contained soft carbonation, was transparent and caramel brown in color.  Its aroma contained notes of medium malts hops and mild caramel.  Its mouth feel is initially bitter hoppy with a lingering  bitter palate and a hoppy aftertaste.  Its flavor contained caramel hoppy  notes.  An above average brew.
Pours a nice hazy golden orange color.  Aromas of nice citrus/grapefruit hops.  Flavor starts malty and the hops kick in, nice crisp bitter finish.

12oz bottle acquired in trade with DarkElf (thanks!). Poured a dark amber color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of toffee, flowers, toasted malts and caramel. Tastes of caramel, oranges, and toasted malts. Nice creamy and smooth body.

Aroma, slight maltiness, low to no aroma
Apperance= Dark red/lt brown, copper notes
Flavor= Non cloying beer, blanced slightly malty and mellow roastiness
Palate= Medium body
Overall= a well balanced beer with slight maltiness and an earthy hop note

(12 oz bottle: BevMo in La Jolla, CA) Much more flavorful than I was expecting, and not only that, its a really good flavor too.  Lots of toasty and slightly roasty malt leads the way, with mild sweetness and a somewhat light yet sufficiently balancing hoppy bitterness.  A solid, deeply toasty maltiness dominates the nose.  Medium-full bodied, perfectly carbonated, nice and round on the palate with a dry, long-lasting and always balanced finish.  This is a pretty beer, boasting a clear, deep, rich, ruddy amber body thats really pushing a shade of brown, and a tall, light-tan head that gradually settles to a bubbly, wide ring.  Lacing is scattered, but plentiful.  ESBs tend to be a more subtle and perhaps refined, if I can use that word, but this one is very bold.  This is a much darker roasted beer than most ESBs, and just packed with flavor, and maybe thats why Im liking this so much.  Good stuff.

Bottle poured a dark amber with an amber head. Aromas of toffee,citrus, and dark bread. Palate was medium bodied and slightly dry. Flavors of roasted malt, citrus, and some floral notes with a slightly astringent dry finish.
on tap at the brewery. my favorite of the bunch of brews i had here.  well balanced, full flavored with a crisp finish.  great amber/red color.

From a bottle (with a twist-cap, no less!)
Pours a dark amber orange with an adequate head
Limited aroma but a nice drinkable bitters; amply hopped with a pleasant if relatively straightforward flavor and finish. This is a plebian beer, but it goes down very nicely and for bottled beer from the cash bar at a conference, we were quite happy to drink this one under the midnight sun during a recent trip to Fairbanks.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is medium to dark amber.

Aroma is moderately malty (cookie, caramel), moderately hoppy (grapefruit, orange, resin).

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation, moderately astringent.

Its a bit abrasive in the mouth, being fairly citric and astringent, and the hops arent really my style (not all bad, but a little too green/resinous for me).  But it does have a pretty good malt presence too.  Good.
Creamy caramel malt aroma. Sweetish caramel, biscuit malt flavor, creamy smooth texture, mildly citric bitter balance in the finish.
Very nice beer! El sabor (un rico amargor) es casi perfecto al tomarla y despues de pasarla deja una buena sensacion. El aroma es una muy buena presentacion de lo que se va a tomar

Pours a copper color with a decent straw colored head that sticks around for a while.  Aromas are hoppy, metalic and not as citrusy or flowery as some others, but appealing non the less.  The taste is good and the mouthfeel lingers. It has a fullness, not watery and is quite nicely dry...no sweet aftertastes that I dont like.  One of my Alaskan favorites. It would be good to put this one in a taste-off with the Sockeye Red IPA and the Alaskan Pale Ale.

Definite hoppy overtones in the aroma but well done.  A fresh-crushed caramel malt and a yeasty fruitiness with a touch of acrid (good) black malt complete the rest of the complex aroma.  Red/ orange in color with a light tan head that dissipates quickly.  Flavor is nicely balanced between a light caramel maltiness and pungent, sweet hops, though the overall impression is that the beer is quite dry.  Nicely bitter and malty at the same time.  A little less acidity and this beer would fatten up nicely for style.

Attractive copper hue with mild carbonation and a foamy, off-white head that left scattered lace. Pleasant sylvan hop character in the nose which also has abundant toastiness, caramel, and cherry. Nice balance of lightly sweet caramel malt, warm toasty bread crusts, and subdued hop flavor and bitterness. Would make a very good cask ale. This stood up to a long road in the bottle from Wrangell, Alaska to Washington, DC to Albuquerque, NM.

Nice copper amber color. Head disappeared quickly. Orange on the aroma, very smooth going down. Sweetness on the tale end of the finish.  I havent liked many ESBs, but this I would come back to readily. Poured this from a bottle I brought back from a trip to Alaska. Seemed to travel well.

Poured a deep ruby brown color with a thin light beige head. The nose was fresh and pungent with flowery hops and a huge buttery maltiness. The Taste started with a zip of citrusy orange, not as floral as anticipated by the aroma. A hint of caramel sweetness arrives with a slight buttery edge. The end brings a firm dose of hops finishing it off nicely. The feel was medium/thin, but the beer was extremely drinkable. This would be the perfect session beer as the taste is more than interesting enough to hold your attention.

Bottle: Copper, minor haze, large off-white head, frothy, lattice like lacing, virtually no carbonation.   Wet malt aroma, almond paste (marzipan actually), soft graininess, even a tad floral.   Well balanced start, a bit chewy on the malts with a soft hop presense.   Very easy to kick back.   No ashtray or nasty musty graininess like so many others.   Moderate body and mouthfeel.   Very soft hop bitterness lingers after the light finish.   Light, well balanced, clean finish, rather enjoyable.

Small light brown head, good retention and a nice lace. Clear amber/copper color. Spicey hop nose, lightly floral, backed by a light grainy maltiness. Medium body, lightly creamy. Medium sweet malts, bready, lightly piney with solid notes of caramel malts. All nicely balanced, an easy quaffer. Finish is dry, malty and lightly fruity. Thanks Stephen!

Bottle. Thanks to jsquire for sharing this one. Small tan head that was mostly lasting, sparse lacing, fine-large sized bubbles, uncarbonated, transparent, and an orange brown hue. Malty, hoppy, sweet, caramel, and a citrus nose. Btter, hoppy and malty flavor. Palate was tingly. Medium body.

Bottle... Clear amber ale with an American iced tea nose and flavor. Minor notes of clover honey and chicken broth in the floral aroma with a whisper of light molasses. Malty, but well-balanced flavor thanks to generous hopping.  Medium to full-bodied with lively carbonation.  Lengthy, moderately bitter, dry finish. Not one of my favorite styles, but this is a qualtiy brew. The Alaskan brewing company hasnt failed me yet. Mad props go out to darkelf for the bottle!
Poured an amber color with a medium head.  sweet and citrus aroma.  Flavor was malty with a mild hoppiness. Nice session brew.  Thanks DarkElf

This beer pours a deep amberish red color with a thin foamy pearlish head which dissipated quickly. Little lacing if any was left in or around my glass. The aroma is fruity sweet with hops florals, citrus and caramel maltiness in the nose. The flavor is medium to full bodied and creates a nice layer of tongue coating maltiness. Very little bittering noted until about mid-beer when an acetic sting of dryness begins to eat away at your esophagus. Malty backbone, some hopping bitterness, but heavily prickeling carbonation. Dry, tangy and somewhat sticky body. The dryness is a serious concern here, but otherwise interesting.

A slightly cloudy amber with a foamy tan head which I drank on my 29th birthday.  Very, very nice malt aroma, somewhat sweet but also a bit toasty.  Aroma is very nice, but somewhat one sided.  Fabulous palate balance.  Nutty and malty, some carmel sweetness a toasty malt and more nuttyness.  Then on top of that, ther is a very plesant hop balance.  This is a good beer from begining to end.
Pours an amber color. Smell consists of hops and sweet citric aromas. Flavor is bitter and somewhat malty. Finish is bitter as well.
Clear amber colour. tangy bitter citric hoppy nose. smooth malt fore tasre with bitter hoppy finish.
Lives up to its name as an ESB.  Has a definite bite to it. Best Alaskan beer Ive had so far.  Cant wait to go back to my homestate and drink it like a native.

From the bottle, the aroma reminded me somehow of fishing -- perhaps theres a little phenolic fishing worm thing going on. Kind of a cool label that reminded me of the  Hurricane Reef flying boat.  Burnt orange. Very drinkable, somewhat simple, sweet, bitter and thinnish -- lets call it session weight.  A litle coffee or cocoa -- almost akin to a mild.  A medium to medium light hopping.

Dark copper appearance; sweet caramel like aroma with some sweet wort-like notes. Bittersweet notes, and some light citrusy undercurrents make this a most delectable and pleasant bitter. Finishes very smooth and clean, a most drinkable ESB.

Draft, from mini keg. Good nose, carmel citrusy. Great red color. Small head that faded. Bitter flavors. Grapefruit mainly, carmel in background. Creamy mouthfeel. Dry bitter finish. Great brew. Had this at Sandy beach in Juneau as part of tour with beer cruise. Some of brewery crew were there. Good time
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text:
Good stuff. My family went on vacation to Alaska, I stayed home and worked. This was my consolation, and let me tell you, I feel better already. Absolutely gorgeous deep red color with a nice tan head. Smells hoppy. 

"Bitter" is a harsh word, really. I would say instead that its sweet and hoppy, with a wonderful, yummy fullness. Hmmm... only five left.
I got this stuff for $3.99 a six pack so I didnt think it would be very good but it was awesome.  It was better than most beers that cost 3 times as much.  Smooth tasting.
This was a tasty beer. Nicely balanced between hops and malt, I wish I could get this locally.

Clear dark mahogany/ruby, nice sticky lacing & head. Off-white color, lots of carbonation. The aroma is toasty with spicy hops & sweetness, very balanced malt body. The flavor has a creamy malt balance & delicious hops. I dont know if its the mass amoutns of lesser beers before this but its incredibly tasty. The finish is toasty, spicy, smooth, delicious!

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2005 Bright amber with a ruby glow. Moderate carbonation. Big maltiness with a hint of toasty-sweet caramel and a bigger hint of dark chocolate cake. Flowery-grassy hops, with quite a bit of bitterness. Pretty good ESB.

Can you say Cascade?  Not very malty, as advertised.  Very Cascadian aroma and flavor, a nice example of how to display American hops.  Too bad Im tired of Cascade right now.  Quality beer nonetheless.

Nice copper red color -- similar to the ambet with more orange tinge to it.  Head dissipates quickly. Good, but different from what I expect in ESB.  Missed the smooth, slight buttery taste that Fullers and Redhook have.  Nice spicy hop additions in the nose and finish, but not enough malt to balance it out. Overall very good, but maybe not a true ESB?
user_location: Palm Beach Gardens, FL, Florida, USA

text: Copper-red colour with a pale yellow creamy head.  Slight haze.  Spicy malty aroma with notes of piny Northwestern hops.  Softly carbonated with a simple light malt taste and a pine/fir hop flavour.  Medium length bitter finish.  Good body and very well-done.

Nice reddish color, the head was small and didn't last long. Malty smell with a little hops. Nice blend of malty sweet flavor with a good blend of hops over it. Not an extra special beer if you ask me, but ok.

12oz bottle-pours a very nice copper hue with a smooth off white head-medium carbonation.  aroma of caramel malts, earth and citrus hops, and slightly metallic.  nice medium palate/body with earthy hops and nice bready malts-very sweet finish.  One of the better representations of the style.  Thanks to Jsquire for the trade :)

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2005 Poured reddish copper with a head that started around 30% of the volume and remained sturdy for several minutes.  Nice citric aroma.  Decent hopped flavors, yet well malted.  Good beer.

Beer pours light amber/copper color with a off white dissipating head.  Aroma is appropriate for the style: fairly malty with light hops.  Flavor is nice.  Seems to be an excellent interplay between the malt sweetness and the hop bitterness.  In the case of this beer the interplay almost rises to the level of a skirmish.  Nice battle for the taste buds to sort out.  Good bitter.

Non-existent head, very low carbonation.  Very nice red/amber color.  Nose is buttery carmel with a hint of pine.  Taste is very mild with a little bit of hop bite, nothing complex here.  Finish is very smooth for an ESB.  Nice session beer.

Deep amber color with hints of ruby make this look like an ESB should look. Caramel malt and hops come to the nose and the flavor is a well balanced echo of the aroma that ends with a slightly bitter hop finish. Not bad.

Reddish hue with amber highlights that produced a small white frothy head but little lace. The aroma hints of pine, grapefruit, biscuit, caramelized malts, grassy and floral hops, and dusty yeast esters. The taste is a sweet malt base with a solid dose of crisp and bitter hops. Citric undertones causes the mouth to water. Straight forward, simple ESB, missing the chalky tones of the better british examples however. Good enough to do the job, worthy of 2 or 3 in a session.

Dark copper appearance with a fluffy tan head.  Big malty nose full of sour wheat and some light sweet hops.  Mouthfeel is very creamy, and the flavor revolves around wheat, corn, maple, some light-biting hops, and some roasted malts.  Very good.

Copper/brown color and minimal head make this sucker appear to be an ESB.  Aromas of dirt, grass, herbal tea...mouthwatering.  Malt sweetness and in-your-face dry and hoppy (absolutely NW flavor) finish is good.  Another Alaskan I wish it had been easier to find.
esb have never been my cup of tea to me they always taste like coffee and they are way to dark
Pours with a frothy white head the quickly dissipates.  Translucent amber.  Malty,but lacking the sulfur, it has all the right malt and hops.  Good ESB, Thanks Loweredsixth

A cherry amber with a small off-white head.  Initial aroma is citrus(orange/grapefruit) that gives way to a fuggle hop aroma, caramel malts.  A caramel taste with a musty hop, dry finish.  A very good ESB.
(draft) Clear copper with small tan head, nice lacing.  Aroma is earthy and mild sweet.  Taste is earthy bitter, hint of floral.  Nice earthy bitter finish.  Light/medium body.

Thin, off-white head that does not linger long. The beer has a deep, clear, ruby red color and a wonderful aroma of piney hops with just a bit of malty sweetness and a hint of caramel. Medium to full body with light carboantion, the mouthfeel is smooth and creamy right through to the finish. The flavor is malty up front with a touch of caramel and the finish is long and slightly bitter from the hops. Well balanced and very drinkable, this is very nice ESB.

Clear copper color,small tight tan head that had a decent staying power.Mild malt aroma with a light citrus hint and decent hop presence.The taste is mildly fruity at first then it changes to a semi-bitter hops taste,lightly spicy,with the after taste being mostly grapefruit and hops.Definately a good brew and very drinkable with just the right amount of everything IMO.

Pretty glowing ruby/brown color with a nice beige head. The aroma was full of hops...citrus and floral tones...with some burnt caramel. The flavor was more sweet...caramel and malt. Crisp, clean feel with a semi-dry finish. Very enjoyable session beer.
I could certainly put a lot of this stuff down. Doughy/piney aroma with apricots. Beautiful appearance, nice finish. A bit of smokiness...this has it all. Could be my new go-to beer?
citrus hop aroma, beautifully amber, watery and grainy with a slight hop bite

Light garnet red in appearance with moderate cap of foam.  Nose is not too pronounced; malty, nutty.  Flavors are balances well, with some lactic taste, caramel, some nuttiness.  Restrained overall and a less British approach to a bitter.  Bitterness is evident in finish.

Very thin head--amber color.  Malty aroma--hint
of caramel.  Nice flavor, malty and finishes with 
a decent amount of bitterness.  Slightly sweet.  
Not sure if it is an ESB, but it makes a fine Amber.

Nice hops aroma - floral, herbal, some oil/grapefruit. Orange-amber clear w/off-white small head. Palate is med watery w/med hi carbonation. Starts slightly sweet w/decent malts. Big hops flavor but mostly hi level of bittering. Some alcohol, bland sugar. Bitter finish & after. Refreshing.

Pours a clear copper color, modest head that quickly subsides.  Lots of malt in the nose, no discernable hops.  Very nice ESB, small hops taste in the finish, right up there with Alesmith Anvil in my opinion.

This is really one of the only brews by Alaskan that I didn't enjoy all that much. Color is a lighter amber, thin off-white head faded leaving minimal light spots of lace. Very acidic flavor and bite, bitterness should be sweet and nice, this had a taste of generic aspirin in the finish that I just didn't like. I highly doubt it was a bad batch cuz all the others I had by Alaskan were great. Had a good smell of floral sweetness and light malt but that didn't carry over in the taste department for me. I've diffenately had better ESB.
Bottled. Nice beer. Wasn't to bitter. Godd hop bite to it.
Light sweet aroma. Rich amber-brown color with a small fast fading head. Start is caramel sweet and the finish lightly hop bitter.
Flowery hop aroma with a strong taste of caramel malt.  Very rich with a mild, but tight, bitter finish.
Amber color.  Fruity aroma (grapefruit?) fresh hops.  A bit of caramel, nice hop bite, so refreshing, a bit floral.
(Bottle) Copper body with beige head. High carbonation. Good bitterness throughout. Very likable!

intense amber/ruby body with a foamy tan head.  plenty of carbonation.  spritzy, creamy, fruity and slightly bitter.  Initiates with a nice malt presence:dry barley grains and a hint of alcohol.  Full and lively palate, almost foamy.  clean and crisp thereafter.
Bottle.  A dark amber color with a tan head.  A sweet caramel malt aroma that is quite impressive.  A coating burnt malt flavor that settles well in the aftertaste.

Copper color with a rocky, tan head and a sweet, grainy nose.  Lots of grainy malt to this one, but I wouldn't call it "roasted overtones."  There was a sort of grapefruit rind bitterness in the finish, but not really the bitterness characteristics I expect from an ESB.  My rating may be influenced because this followed the Schlafly's Winter ESB, but I don't think so.

A beautiful amber, small head. Wonderful aroma, a fruity boqueet with nice floral hoppy nose. Ahhh, I could sniff this all night! Delicious, well balanced just sweet enough with just enough bittering hops. I concur with Merc's comment" A beer I would like to always have in my stock pile". A winner from the lads up north! Thanks to my Mother and sister for sending this nectar!
Amber with lasting beige head. Light unripe hop nose. Malty midtaste with a green hop finish

Solid clear copper, topped with a slowly fading head, this is a meandering, easy going beer. Its just plain lazy, but in a good way. Much like a nice hammock on lazy summer day, or a comfy chair at the end of the day, it welcomes you to put your feet up and relax.   Nice mellow edges of malt blend with feather light touches of hops. This is an everyday subtle session beer. I think Im gonna find a couch, put my feet up, and have a few.

Light brown color, medium head. Roasted malts, medium hops. There is a smokiness to this beer. Nice malty character pervades this beer. Some malt sweetness. Finish is very smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter, malty with some sweetness. A very complex flavor to this beer.

very nice ESB.
dark bronze color, foamy  head,  floral  and spicy aroma.
good balance of malt and hop tastes.
dry bitter finish.

Handsome ale--deep red-amber color--very healthy cream-hued head. Fine fruity aroma, citrusy but a little sweet at the same time--different...A refreshing hoppy wave greets the palate, accompanied by a carbonated tickle. Malt flavors--slightly sweet, slightly roasted, follow behind. Hop dryness and malts nicely balanced in finish as well. Body is about right--enough to have presence, but light enough to ensure its refreshing qualities. This is a nicely balanced brew--one of Alaskas better offerings.

Really a fine brew.  It is indeed bitter, but wonderfully balanced, creating a full flavored, rich beer, with a very nice finish.
Drink Alaskan!
A beer I would like to always have in my stock pile.  Beautifully balanced, a wine like aspect to it.  Only very slightly below the Amber in my book.

Alskan is a great brewery and thank God Bevmo in SoCal carries most of their line - get their brews - they are great!!

Nice deep golden brown appearance. Medium mouthfeel. Excellent balance between hops and malt!! Just enough sweetness from the malt and bitter bite from the hops make this a complex treat for your taste buds. At $7 a sixer here in SoCal a solid value - excellent ESB and usually onhand at my house.

This is truly nice ale. Not much of a head but a very fruity nose, which smells like kiwi, watermelon and fresh Alaskan air. It also sports a good flavor, which smells very much like the aroma with the extra special bitter. One of the few Ill buy again. All you beer coinsures need to try it out.

Brillian red-amber hue topped with a fluffy head--this is one of the very best ESBs.  Lovely candied barley wine aroma that is full of figs and raisins. Again, the flavor more closely resembles that of a barley wine than of an ESB.  Smooth candied taste is not as incredible as the aroma--but still fine tasting.  The body is smooth, winy, and quaffable--not a bit cloying. Slight malt presence adds a balancing note to the candy edge.
Good coloring, and has a nice bitter finish. Not too much, though. Just enough to let you know what youre drinking.
Nice balance of malty and bitters in the taste. Has a very nice appearance also.... Overall very impressed and reccommend trying it!
Beautiful amber color. Bitter, but not harsh. Normally I dont like bitter beer, but this is an excellent exception.
Definetly top three of ESBs Ive tried
Loved it, what is there I can say.  One of the best ESBs I have tried, but still deosnt compare to england bitters.

mmmmm. silky smooth with the perfect hop malt balance. slightly light in body, however......
APROVED!
Chewy malts, earthen flavors and a bitter bite at the end.  The best American ESB that Ive had, and the star of the local beer festival I attended.
Decent ESB. Nice looking. Loads of caramel malts with a subtle mix of earthy hoppiness and some Cascade notes as well. Very crisp yet sweet and drinkable.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2007 I though this was very fresh and tasty.  My mom brought some back from Oregon along with their others offerings.  I found it rich in malts and hops in the aroma and semi-chewy with good body and decent head after a hard poor.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Caramel malt nose and flavour with some hop bitterness to balance.  This is one of the top US ESBs that I have tried.
After being pleasantly surprised by other Alaskan offerings, I was let down by this rather bland bitter.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2003 The color on the pour is a limpid burnished copper, the head modest, frothy and the color a light beige with the lace a fine covering sheet. Nose is floral, buttery, crisp and clean, a real sniffer with the start sweet and full of malt, top is middling in feel. Finish has a delectable hop presence, acidity moderate and the aftertaste quite dry, and a real credit to the style.
